title: The community's median skill with Zed/Yasuo is absurd.
body:
This has always seemed like an elephant in the room to me but I've rarely or never seen attention brought to it, maybe because we're too busy meme'ing about the 0/12 "My Team's Yasuo." Both of these Champions are billed as being ultra-difficult and ultra-complex to play effectively, requiring mechanical prowess beyond that which is required by other Champions. Yet both are as common as grass and the median competency of players who play Zed and Yasuo is just absolutely unbelievable. Even that garden variety 0/12 Yasuo is mechanically outperforming most people in the match, and you're left speechless when that Zed in your low Silver game just pulled off a stunt that you would expect to see in Diamond.

I'm confused about how I should perceive this. I'm a Mid-Silver player (so, not good), and I just feel like my peers are over-performing with these Champions beyond what they should be capable of. Players who are not good should not be able to access 75%-80% of the efficiency of complex Champions like Zed or Yasuo. That, for me, is the elephant in the room.

What do you think?

Riven is more animation cancel based. While both Zed and Yasuo can utilize animation cancels, they're more combo based than animation cancel based. I'd argue that animation cancelling is harder to master than combos.
I never understood the point of having animation cancelling being the pinnacle of a champion's skill expression. Is it healthy, or do I just not get it?

I personally find it unhealthy, because it solely relies on improper coding to allow champions to do much more damage than they're meant to do. It definitely does take skill though. Inputting movement commands as abilities are casting to move while using abilities isn't easy, but it also isn't fair for those who are able to do it. That's why a lot of people hate Riven: there's a lot of montages with Riven at below 30% HP, someone comes to kill her and she stun locks them while autoing between each Q and 100-0's them

It's not really healthy and it was labeled a bug a long time ago in Rito's spaghetti code - a "behind the scenes" on Riven basically said that it was something that they thought about fixing and then decided they "liked it".

It's not actually particularly balanced or fair since animation canceling makes the champ required to be balanced around it, much like an overpowered item or keystone. So players who don't use the mechanic will never get the full extent of the champ and will often underperform while simultaneously being a mechanic that isn't told to you at face value - you're forced to work on it yourself.

That has some attraction to it - you do get a feeling of really "mastering" a champion if you have to go super in-depth into the finer points. However, it gives vastly mixed signals in a competitive game where your ability to calculate something can win or lose a game for you, and these are completely uncalculable. You'd notice this a ton if you went from one game against a Riven that never animation canceled into a game with one that does - and it is a very noticeable difference because the second one you're going to get stomped when you're pretty sure you can win.

"But Riven is modeled after fighting games, where these kinds of things are meant to be a feature." Except League doesn't share that - most of League's champions have zero animation canceling whatsoever (or at least no beneficial ones), and it's not even a natural part of the game, so the fact people say that it's okay is absolutely confounding.

A majority of even Silver players are honestly pretty solid in their mechanics.  That means in a fight, Yasuo and Zed are going to be nightmares to deal with in such a low elo when you can't be expected to have a team that will actively work cohesively to try and utilize their various powers to uplift each other and suppress these powerful enemies.  I have honestly told myself many times, "If pros play Zed/Yasuo even 30% better than the dudes I'm seeing, then their opponents must be dying in the loading screen because there's no way to singlehandedly handle some of these dudes."

Mechanical skill will only take you so far, so these folks tend to stay in Silver because even though they are a veritable meat grinder of champions, they squander that ability by not pushing when they should, not grouping when they should, not building what they should, not utilizing proper team play and probably getting a big head while trying to handle everything themselves... not to mention playing the vision game and actually _acting_ on it.

Basically, yes, I agree 100% that most of the Zed/Yasuo players out there really know how to kick someone's ass, and although that skill alone will not climb the ladder for them, it certainly creates a hellish environment for the lower tiers of gameplay where you're expected to have to handle them all on your own.

Typically speaking the main thing that keeps silver players down is poor macro play. It is especially a problem when MULTIPLE people on the team don't know how to macro. You can USUALLY wrangle in some people with pings, but there will almost always be one person who doesn't know what they are doing AND they think they know better than the shotcaller and won't follow the call and instead leave you with 4v5 scenarios while they get nothing. The amount of people that don't group and get nothing from it in lower elos is astonishing. If you aren't going to group you better take a tower or two and not just get US all killed to hard engage while you farm a few creeps for 2 minutes and then recall while they are STILL pushing mid.

Oof.  Yeah you're hitting on some real prevalent issues, no doubt. Zed becomes a lot less complex looking when you realize the only thing he actually has to aim is his Q and then you really just have to have your cursor floating over whoever you jump on with R. The old RWEQR combo is much less complicated than most think and, with practice, can be executed in a very, very small amount of time. This is further proven when you realize that if the Zed suddenly thinks anything is gonna go wrong and he won't be able to get the combo off before getting off'd himself, he can just press R to instantly get the heck outta there.

Zed is a "hard champion", but only in the sense that you need time to perfect him. He has a ton of safety nets that make bad players not too heavily punished for messing up on him, and I'm saying this not in a "Zed is OP" way. I'm just stating my beliefs on a champion that many falsely consider to be a "hard and punishing champion to mess up on".

I don't think so.  Zed and Yas are both easy to play at a 'competent level.  Their skill floor is low.  Their skill ceiling, however, is pretty high.  I'm not in your games, so I could be wrong, but I doubt silver Yas's are reliably pulling off the "keyblade".

{{champion:157}} 2 sec cd's w/o building any cd items or taking it in runes... when your cd's are that low, you can miss 60% of your abilities completely and still land them as frequently as most champs hitting with 100% success rate. Champ doesn't require nearly as much skill as people claim. And honestly, some of the "simple" champions are actually more difficult than the credit we give to them. Take swain for instance... he's fragile enough (even w/ zhonya and roa) to die pretty fast in teamfights if he's not hella fed and he runs in.  But if he doesn't run in at some point, he doesn't deal damage. So it's not per-say "mechanical" skill, but it requires more skill than some other champs on knowing the optimal time to run in, the optimal time to zhonya during fights, which enemies to run after if they split up, which target to pull in if chasing several people who split up, etc.

Now, played at MAX potential, sure maybe a yas requires some high skill, but to play an average yasuo actually takes probably less skill than to play some other champions. And a SIMILAR (but not the same) argument can be made for zed. Also... lower elo means your OPPONENTS will have lower skill level. Which makes it easier to pull stuff off. And people have a bad habit this season of not even trying once their team falls behind. They just go through the motions and make bad decisions which they would normally never make because "it's over" or "we lost already". Once in a blue moon I'll see someone who has truly amazing mechanics, but it's pretty rare. A vayne that can jump in 2v4 with me through a bunch of enemy aoe, cc, and burst and survive to rack up 3 kills. A riven that actually knows how to combo properly and with SPEED that makes me have to actually work to win lane. A zed that knows how to w in during the middle of a crazy fight and ult onto a carry for an assassination via coordinating with our jg or toplaner rather than some hella fed zed who just flashes in 1v5 or 5v5 and kills whomever he wants purely because he's 12/2/0.

I tried out Zed to see if this high skill requirement held true. And I have to say his E can drain his energy like he just ran a goddamn marathon. But other than that, he's kinda face-rolly in lane. 

Outside of lane I found it kinda pointless to dive into team fights because I'd see GAs and Zhonya's/Stopwatches and just kept getting cockblocked while trying to do my job of bursting squishies. I also realized that Zhonya's/GA doesn't mean a whole lot to him in a 1v1. It's only in a team fight where it's really a pain to deal with. In a 1v1, he can just wait out the untargetability and burst them a second time. So I just kinda split pushed and hoped a lone squishy would come to try and stop me. Though without attack speed or auto attack steroids, he's a lot slower at taking towers than say {{champion:24}} or {{champion:75}} .

Zed in team fights DOES have a high skill floor because you have to deal with CC, being burst immediately after ulting, using your shadows to dodge skillshots, making sure your ult actually manages to kill a carry, making sure you have enough energy to do what you need to do. And a lot of the times when I tried using my ult to teleport back to safety, I found someone waiting for me to either kill me or lock me down after I used up all my energy trying to kill someone else. So I eventually stopped feeling as safe as I thought I would be.

So, from experience, Zed vs most standard mid laners requires very little skill to play at an adequate level, while mid-late game you kinda have to think about what you're doing. Just my 2 cents though.
You have to keep in mind that being good at a champion, and being good at league. Are two very different things.
